revision.text:
{{Outdated|date=March 2016}}
'''AUTOECO''' is a [[vehicle show]] about TecnoEcology for the Automobile world, in [[Oval Lingotto]], [[Turin]], in September. The motto is "Review of the ecologic [[automobile]]"
In the show meet the more important automotive marks, the centers of planning and realization of systems of [[ecological propulsion]], the producers of alternative fuels and the centers for the installation of bi-fuel injection kits in order to introduce the last innovations and in order to treat one of the greatest topics of present time.
== Current == 7, 8 and 9-September-2007.
== Categories == * [[Biofuel]] sections: ** [[Biodiesel]]. ** [[Bioethanol]]. ** Technologies and complete systems of biofuel production. * Conventions. * Ecology Vehicles ([[electric vehicle]]s). * [[Hybrid vehicle]]s. * [[Hydrogen vehicle]]s. * Laboratories of research and development. * Polifuel technology. * Studies of engineering and planning . * [[Vegoil]]s.
== External links == * [http://www.ttgexpo.com/autoeco.php?PHPSESSID=74f4332e677fbcef057b88f5ed719114 Official website]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.
{{auto-org-stub}}
[[Category:Auto shows]]

page.title: All Hands And Hearts - Smart Response

revision.text:
<noinclude>{{Infobox non-profit | name = All Hands And Hearts - Smart Response | image = File:All_Hands_And_Hearts_-_Smart_Response_new_logo_(2018).png | caption = | map = | map_size = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | map_alt = <!-- map alt text --> | map_caption = | map2 = | type = 501(c)3 non-profit organization | tax_id = US Tax ID #20-3414952 / UK charity number 1139938 | registration_id = | founded_date = 2005 | founder = David Campbell, Petra Němcová | predecessor =All Hands Volunteers | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merged = | successor =All Hands And Hearts - Smart Response | location = 6 County Road, Suite 6 Mattapoisett, MA 02739 | addnl_location = | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people = David Campbell, Chair and Founder, Petra Němcová, Vice Chair and Co-Founder, Erik Dyson, Executive Director | area_served = Worldwide | products = | services = Natural Disaster Recovery and Aid | focus = | mission = "To provide immediate, effective and sustainable support to communities in need by harnessing the energy and commitment of dedicated volunteers."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/about/ |title=About | All Hands Volunteers |publisher=Hands.org |date=2012-05-15 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> | method = | revenue = $3,929,567 (2013) $7,278,917 (2017) | disbursed = | expenses = $2,913,607 (2013)<ref>{{cite web|author = |url=https://www.dropbox.com/sh/o2014b77rgz9n1v/7Ld8qiojUL/AHV%20AR%202013%20FORWEB.pdf |title=All Hands Financial Report 2013 |publisher=All Hands Volunteers |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> $6,119,128 (2017) | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | affiliations = | subsid = | owner = | motto = | formerly = Hands On Disaster Response, All Hands Volunteers | website = https://www.allhandsandhearts.org | footnotes = }} '''All Hands And Hearts - Smart Response''' is a U.S.-based, [[501(c)3]] non-profit organization. Founded in September 2005, All Hands provides relief to residents in areas affected by natural disasters in the U.S. and internationally. In late 2017 All Hands Volunteers merged with the Happy Hearts Fund, founded by Czech supermodel and philanthropist, [[Petra Němcová]], to become All Hands and Hearts - Smart Response.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://dujour.com/cities/petra-nemcova-happy-hearts-fund-and-all-hands-volunteers/|title=Petra Nemcova's Happy Hearts Fund and All Hands Volunteers - DuJour|date=2017-12-07|work=DuJour|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref> It is based in [[Mattapoisett, Massachusetts]].
==History==
The organization that would become All Hands Volunteers was co-founded on September 6, 2005 by internet entrepreneur [[Darius Monsef]] and businessman [[David N. Campbell|David Campbell]] after the pair met in Thailand, where they had both gone to work in the aftermath of the [[2004 Sumatran tsunami]] that killed an estimated 230,000 people. Many arriving volunteers found that they were being turned away by established charities, resulting in a group coming together to perform basic tasks, such as clearing debris and building shelters.<ref name="forbes1">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/howardhusock/2013/09/30/not-from-government-here-to-help-3-all-hands-volunteers-cleans-up-superstorm-sandy/ |title=Not From Government, Here to Help (3): All Hands Volunteers Cleans Up Superstorm Sandy |publisher=Forbes |date=2013-09-30 |accessdate=2014-02-13 |first=Howard |last=Husock}}</ref> The pair, along with Pete Kirkwood and Mike Cegielski, two U.S. citizens then living in Thailand, created HandsOnThailand, which brought more than 200 volunteers as well as several hundred thousand dollars to aid in the rebuilding of five [[Phuket]] fishing villages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oleantimesherald.com/news/article_153876ce-df12-11e3-b909-001a4bcf887a.html|title=Alfred State holds 103rd commencement|work=Olean Times Herald |accessdate=2014-10-09}}</ref>
In the aftermath of [[Hurricane Katrina]], the pair joined with other HandsOn volunteers to establish [[Hands On USA|HandsOnUSA]], setting up an operations center in [[Biloxi, Mississippi]] within days of the storm.<ref name="volunteermatch1">{{cite web|url=http://www.volunteermatch.org/search/org269529.jsp |title=All Hands Volunteers Volunteer Opportunities |publisher=VolunteerMatch |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ns.gmnews.com/news/2005-12-29/Front_page/005.html |title=A Hands On experience with disaster, despair | ns.gmnews.com | North South Brunswick Sentinel |publisher=ns.gmnews.com |date=2005-12-29 |accessdate=2014-02-13 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140314195611/http://ns.gmnews.com/news/2005-12-29/Front_page/005.html |archive-date=2014-03-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richardsmith.net/biloxi/handson.html |title=Biloxi, Mississippi, Katrina Recovery |publisher=Richardsmith.net |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> The organization signed on 1,500 volunteers, providing an estimated $2.5 million in volunteer time.<ref name="portlandtribune1">{{cite web|url=http://portlandtribune.com/component/content/article?id=87171 |title=Pamplin Media Group |publisher=Portlandtribune.com |date=2007-05-23 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> HandsOnUSA worked on demolition and construction in the city, as well as clearing away debris and making space for the trailers supplied by the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.projecthope.org/news-blogs/stories/gabrielles-story.html#sthash.tl0J471x.dpuf |title=Remembering Hurricane Katrina |publisher=Project Hope |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> The group remained in Biloxi for five months.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/FinanceProfessorjim_9 |title=Interview with Darius Monsef of HandsonUSA : FinanceProfessor(jim) : Free Download & Streaming : Internet Archive |publisher=Archive.org |date=2001-03-10 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> In January 2006, the group turned the project over to Hands On Network Gulf Coast and changed its name to Hands On Disaster Response (HODR), launching their next recovery project in [[Yogyakarta]], Indonesia in May of the same year, following the [[2006 Yogyakarta earthquake]].<ref name="David Campbell">{{cite web|url=http://www.encore.org/david-campbell |title=David Campbell |publisher=Encore.org |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.niagara.edu/executive-director-of-hands-on-disaster-response-to-speak-at-nu-border-community-service-event/ |title=Executive Director of Hands On Disaster Response to speak at NU Border Community SERVICE Event | NU News |publisher=News.niagara.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
In August 2010, Hands On Disaster Response changed its name to All Hands Volunteers to avoid being confused with other organizations with similar names.<ref name=volunteermatch1 />
In late 2017 All Hands Volunteers merged with The Happy Hearts Fund, created by [[Petra Němcová]], to become All Hands And Hearts - Smart Response.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mysocialgoodnews.com/hands-volunteers-happy-hearts-fund-unite-form-hands-hearts-smart-response-expanding-disaster-relief-efforts-creating-impactful-change-worldwide/|title=All Hands Volunteers and Happy Hearts Fund Unite To Form All Hands and Hearts – Smart Response, Expanding Disaster Relief Efforts and Creating More Impactful Change Worldwide {{!}} My Social Good News|date=2017-11-14|work=My Social Good News|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
In 2018, All Hands And Hearts were ranked #1 on the Classy 100, topping a list of fastest growing NGO's for 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.classy.org/classy-100/2017/all-hands-and-hearts-smart-response|title=Classy.org|website=www.classy.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref>
Also in 2018, All Hands And Hearts - Smart Response has been given a 4 star rank by Charity Navigator. The organisation is currently one of the highest rated charities on Charity Navigator. Only 13% of charities have received at least four consecutive 4-star ratings, indicating that All Hands and Hearts outperforms most of the other 1.5 million charities in America in terms of operational and financial efficiency.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=13109|title=Charity Navigator - Rating for All Hands and Hearts Smart Response|website=Charity Navigator|language=en|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref>
==Volunteer process==
All Hands And Hearts are often amongst the first to respond and the last to leave when co-ordinating relief efforts. When establishing a presence at a new location following a major disaster, the organisation first conducts a thorough assessment to determine the community where they will establish a base, after communicating with local community leadership, following up by inviting a set number of volunteers to join the project base as space and need allows.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.woodworkingnetwork.com/wood-market-trends/woodworking-industry-trends-press-releases/All-Hands-Volunteers-Responds-to-Hurricane-Sandy-178994981.html?source=related#sthash.EY7gEjcg.dpuf |title=All Hands Volunteers Responds to Hurricane Sandy |publisher=Woodworkingnetwork.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> While many large volunteer organizations request that volunteers pay to participate, All Hands Volunteers only requests that volunteers cover their own travel expenses, while the group raises funds to cover the remaining expenses.<ref name="villagesoup1">{{cite web|url=http://sippican.villagesoup.com/p/mattapoisett-residents-gets-all-hands-on-deck/1099234 |title=Mattapoisett residents gets 'All Hands' on deck - By Georgia Sparling - Marion, Mattapoisett, Rochester, MA - Sippican Week VillageSoup |publisher=Sippican.villagesoup.com |date=2014-01-19 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
Volunteers aren't expected to set a minimum set commitment period, staying only as long as they can. In addition, the nature of some of the work volunteers perform (mainly cleanup and demolitions in areas affected by natural disasters) is unskilled labor, meaning that volunteers can immediately take part in recovery efforts with little or no training.<ref name="bsces1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bsces.org/index.cfm/page/Hands-On-Disaster-Response:-Project-Sungai-Geringging/cdid/10701/pid/10371 |title=Hands On Disaster Response: Project Sungai Geringging - BSCES - Boston Society of Civil Engineers Section |publisher=BSCES |date=2009-09-30 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> Work is often limited to physical labor, such as clearing debris or demolishing damaged structures, but has also included building of schools in [[Haiti]], permanent homes in the [[Philippines]], rebuild programmes in the United States following [[Hurricane Sandy]] and other powerful storms as well as ongoing school and community rebuild programmes in [[Nepal]] and [[Peru]].<ref name="forbes1" /><ref name="bsces1" /><ref name="gmanetwork1">{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/314057/news/regions/ngo-initiated-c-de-oro-housing-project-for-sendong-victims-nearly-complete|title=NGO-initiated C' de Oro housing project for 'Sendong' victims nearly complete | News | GMA News Online|date=2013-06-22|publisher=Gmanetwork.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://holidaybenefitconcert.org/About.html|title=Holiday Benefit Concert for Sandy Relief|publisher=}}</ref>
To date, All Hands And Hearts has enabled over 50,000 volunteers from over 45 countries to positively impact and empower over a million people adversely affected by natural disaster.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allhandsandhearts.org|title=All Hands and Hearts - Smart Response {{!}} Powered by Volunteers|website=All Hands and Hearts|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
The organization has engaged volunteers from more than 45 countries, something which is celebrated amongst the volunteer community, lending itself to a positive, welcoming and enriching volunteer experience.<ref name="world1">{{cite web|url=http://world.edu/tsunami-story-hands-volunteers/ |title=Taking on a Tsunami: The story of All Hands Volunteers |publisher=world.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
==Timeline of projects==
=== 2018 === In September 2017, [[Hurricane Maria]] devastated large areas of [[Dominica]]. It was reported that over 90% of structures on the island suffered damage, with widespread loss of electricity and basic facilities. In response, All Hands and Hearts launched a relief programme in April 2018, focused on restoring education to the children of [[Dominica]], in particular the rebuild of the Paix Bouche Primary School. When completed, the school is expected to serve 78 students, with over 200 projected over the next 10 years. The school is also envisioned to provide shelter against future storms, both for students and the local community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/09/maria-devastates-dominica-heads-puerto-rico-170919083417236.html|title=Maria devastates Dominica, heads to Puerto Rico|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref>
Hurricanes [[Hurricane Irma|Irma]] and [[Hurricane Maria|Maria]] bombarded the [[British Virgin Islands]] in September 2017. The islands were subjected to some of the strongest winds in recorded history, decimating the beautiful islands and causing extensive damage to homes, schools, community facilities and utilities across the islands. All Hands and Hearts launched a program help impacted children on the island of [[Tortola]]. A number of schools and care facilities were outlined as needing immediate support, with volunteers helping to clear debris and prepare sites for rebuilds. As the program has progressed through 2018, community programs have been started, with several homes cleared of debris and made safe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bviplatinum.com/news.php?articleId=28710|title=Volunteers Praised For Post Irma Work|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/bvi-hurricane-response/|title=British Virgin Islands Hurricane Response {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
[[Hurricane Maria]] caused widespread destruction in [[Puerto Rico]] during the fall of 2017. After monitoring the situation over recovery efforts, All Hands and Hearts launched a relief program in January 2018, responding to the immediate lack of sanitation, potable water and power outages that continue to affect the island.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/puerto-rico-response/|title=Puerto Rico Recovery {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref> Volunteers have worked to clear debris, muck and clear facilities, homes and infrastructure, assist in sanitation work, gutting damaged areas and preparing sites for rebuild and repair projects. To date over 247 individual jobs have been completed with over 24,000 volunteer hours logged.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://share.insider.thomsonreuters.com/link?entryId=1_hi36iyfj|title=Volunteers Put Work on Hold and Serve in Puerto Rico|website=Thomson Reuters - Production KMC|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foodandwine.com/syndication/why-you-should-go-to-puerto-rico-now|title=Voluntourism in Puerto Rico: How to Help After Hurricane Maria|work=Food & Wine|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref>
In June 2018, heavy tropical rainfall hit the south [[Texas]] coastline, causing severe flash floods and widespread disruption.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/06/21/texas-floods-heavy-rains-inundate-areas-hard-hit-hurricane-harvey/721598002/|title=Days of torrential rain lead to Texas' worst flooding since Hurricane Harvey|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en}}</ref> All Hands and Hearts assessed the ongoing situation and in response set up an immediate response programme in [[Hidalgo County, Texas|Hidalgo county]]. The volunteer team are currently working with local communities to muck and gut homes, clear debris and assist in sanitation and relief in the affected areas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2018/06/20/flash-flood-emergency-in-parts-of-coastal-texas-from-over-a-foot-of-rain/|title=Flash flood emergency in parts of coastal Texas from over a foot of rain|last=|first=|date=|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/south-texas-flash-flood-response/|title=South Texas Flash Flood Response {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== 2017 === In March 2017, All Hands and Hearts launched a relief programme in [[Peru]] in response to the widespread and [[2016–17 South America floods|devastating flooding]] which had affected much of the country since late 2016. A programme was launched in the eastern area of Peru, in the district of [[Piura Province]]. Volunteers worked to remove mud and debris from homes and schools, some of which were found to be almost entirely filled with mud. In August 2017, All Hands and Hearts began the next stage of the programme, to rebuild a number of schools, the first of which has since been completed. Further projects are continuing in Yapatera, including school builds, English lessons, community outreach programmes and schemes focused on empowering women in the local area. An estimated 2,000 students have been returned to education, with over 3,000 people impacted as a result of the programme.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/perufloodrecovery/|title=Peru Flood Recovery {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/peru/all-hands-volunteers-launches-peru-flood-response-program|title=All Hands Volunteers Launches Peru Flood Response Program|work=ReliefWeb|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref>
In September 2017, Hurricanes Maria and Irma devastated large areas of the [[Caribbean]] including the [[British Virgin Islands|British]] and [[United States Virgin Islands|US Virgin Island]]<nowiki/>s, [[Puerto Rico]] and [[Dominica]] leading to widespread damage, loss of electricity and basic facilities. All Hands and Hearts continued to monitor the situation during the ongoing hurricane season, launching programs in 2018 to address continuing issues across the region.<ref>{{Citation|title=Hurricane Maria travels close to Irma's path - CNN Video|url=https://edition.cnn.com/videos/weather/2017/09/18/hurricane-maria-weather-update-pedram-javaheri-sot.cnn|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref>
=== 2016 === In January 2016, winter storms resulted in several tornadoes and severe flooding affecting [[St. Louis|St Louis, Missouri]]. All Hands and Hearts responded to the urgent need for debris removal, sanitation and clearing of damaged infrastructure.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/all-hands-vs-goliath/|title=All Hands vs. Goliath {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
In August 2016, [[2016 Louisiana floods|heavy flooding severely affected the state of Louisiana.]] Extremely heavy rainfall resulted in flash flood warnings and the destruction or damage of over 60,000 homes, displacing over 8,000 people. All Hands and Hearts launched a relief programme on August 18th, focusing on clearing debris, assisting in sanitation projects and removing flood damaged structures. Efforts were centred in [[Denham Springs, Louisiana|Denham Springs]] where 90% of homes and business were affected. Volunteer teams also worked in the [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]] area.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/louisiana-flood-response-2/|title=Louisiana Flood Response {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2016/08/25/louisiana-flood-victims-desperate-volunteers-money/89350386/|title=Louisiana flood victims desperate for volunteers, money|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref>
The ongoing earthquake relief programme in [[Nepa]]<nowiki/>l continued to be heavily active throughout 2016, with a number of school projects being completed in [[Nuwakot District|Nuwako]]<nowiki/>t and [[Kathmandu]].
In October 2016, [[Hurricane Matthew]] struck the Caribbean and southern United States with [[North Carolina]], [[Haiti]] and [[Florida]] being worst hit. Widespread flooding and storm damage was reported across much of the region, prompting a relief response to be launched on October 6th, aimed at clearing debris, fallen trees, preparing rebuild sites and environmental cleanups Domestic efforts were centred in [[North Carolina]] and [[Florida]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/hurricane-matthew-response-copy/|title=Hurricane Matthew Response - USA {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/haiti/hurricane-matthewhaiti-update-all-hands-volunteers|title=Hurricane Matthew/Haiti Update from All Hands Volunteers|work=ReliefWeb|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref>
===2015 === Between February - March 2015, All Hands and Hearts responded to [[January 2015 North American blizzard|heavy winter weather]] which struck across the eastern United States coast. Volunteers in [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]] assisted residents in clearing snow and co-ordinated with local authorities to facilitate welfare checks.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/boston-snow-response/|title=Boston Snow Response {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
Two years after Superstorm Sandy, All Hands opened its third rebuild project in [[Brooklyn]], New York, in January to help those whose homes were damaged by the hurricane. Similar to reconstruction on Staten Island, the work included minor framing, drywall installation, mudding and taping, and painting.<ref>[http://www.silive.com/news/index.ssf/2012/12/volunteers_continue_clean_up_e.html Volunteers continue clean up efforts in Midland Beach | SILive.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
That same month, [[Malawi]] experienced heavy flooding and All Hands worked with the [[International Organization for Migration]] (IOM) to track the status and needs of those displaced by the floods.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iom.int/news/assessment-flood-affected-malawi-highlights-need-recovery-and-transition-support|title=Assessment of Flood-Affected Malawi Highlights Need for Recovery and Transition|last=Chimenya|first=Brenda|date=2015-05-01|publisher=International Organization for Migration|accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref> A few months later, All Hands phased into rebuild work and began the digging and bricking of irrigation wells to provide water to crops affected by the floods.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/malawirebuild/|title=Malawi Flood Rebuild|author=All Hands Volunteers|date=2015-07-25|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref>
On April 25, [[April 2015 Nepal earthquake|a 7.8 earthquake]] struck [[Nepal]], followed by a major [[May 2015 Nepal earthquake|7.3 aftershock on May 12th.]] Over 9,000 people were killed, with over 23,000 injured. Mass devastation to infrastructure, homes and further loss of life followed. All Hands and Hearts deployed a team of disaster response experts to help distribute goods and coordinate local volunteer efforts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2015/05/01/403562260/you-want-to-go-to-nepal-and-help-out-is-that-a-good-idea|title=You Want to Go to Nepal and Help Out: Is That a Good Idea?|last=Cole|first=Diane|date=2015-05-02|publisher=NPR|accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref> Teams then began working in [[Kathmandu]] and [[Sindhupalchowk District]] clearing debris and demolishing unsafe structures.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/tanya-glanvillewallis/nepal-where-hands-and-hea_b_14631566.html|title=NEPAL: Where Hands And Hearts Meet|last=Glanville-Wallis|first=Tanya|date=2017-02-06|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> This work was followed by building temporary learning centers and homes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interaction.org/crisis-response/all-hands-volunteerss-response-nepal-earthquake-0|title=All Hands Volunteers’ Response to the Nepal Earthquake|author=All Hands Volunteers|publisher=Interaction|accessdate=2015-08-15}}</ref> Since work began in 2015, All Hands and Hearts have led programmes rebuilding eight schools throughout the [[Nuwakot District|Nuwakot]], [[Sindhupalchok District|Sindhupalchowk]], Thulo and [[Kathmandu]] regions, directly impacting around 8,000 children. Over 20,000 people have been positively impacted over the course of the programme's duration, which resumed in late 2017 following the monsoon season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hands.org/projects/nepal-earthquake-recovery/|title=Nepal Earthquake Recovery {{!}} All Hands|work=All Hands|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref> All Hands and Hearts continue to be focused on returning school facilities to local children, with the latest project in Haibung nearing completion as of March 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2015/05/01/403562260/you-want-to-go-to-nepal-and-help-out-is-that-a-good-idea|title=You Want To Go To Nepal And Help Out. Is That A Good Idea?|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.treadright.org/news/project-news/all-hands-hearts-completes-work-nibugaun-school-nepal|title=All Hands and Hearts Completes Work on Nibugaun School in Nepal {{!}} Treadright Foundation|website=www.treadright.org|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref>
===2014=== On April 30, 2014, the All Hands Assessment Team arrived in [[Tupelo, Mississippi]], two days after a tornado outbreak devastated the Southeast United States. All Hands chose to focus their response efforts in [[Itawamba County, Mississippi|Itawamba County]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://orgsync.com/56643/news_posts/73062|title=Mississippi Tornado Disaster Relief Information|last=Franks|first=Megan|date=2014-05-02|publisher=Mississippi State University|accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref> Over the course of their response, 328 volunteers completed 84 jobs, which included basic debris removal, demolition of homes and barns, and significant salvage work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/itawamba-tornado-response/|title=Itawamba Tornado Response|author=All Hands Volunteers|date=2014-06-28|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref> Less than two months later, a set of tornadoes struck the town of [[Pilger, Nebraska]] destroying 80% of the town and injuring dozens. In our two weeks in Pilger, a total of 2,943 All Hands-coordinated volunteers completed work on 35 sites and removed debris in over three-quarters of the town.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/pilger-tornado-response/|title=Pilger Tornado Response|author=All Hands Volunteers|date=2014-07-05|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref> In August [[Detroit]] experienced severe flooding and the All Hands quickly launched Project Detroit to help those in the area begin to recover from the damaging floods, and by project close had gutted and sanitized over 400 homes in the Detroit metro area.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/04/08/make-a-difference-day-awards-detroit/25434631/|title=Make A Difference Day Awards: Flood Recovery in Detroit|last=Wisely|first=John|date=2015-04-08|accessdate=2015-08-14|publisher=USA Today}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mlive.com/news/detroit/index.ssf/2014/12/volunteers_from_around_country.html "Four months after heavy rains, volunteers help Detroiters still struggling with flood damage"]. ''MLive Michigan''.</ref>
As cleanup after Typhoon Yolanda moved toward completion in the Philippines, All Hands shifted their focus towards long-term recovery, concentrating on building permanent homes in both of the cities of [[Ormoc]] and [[Tacloban]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asamnews.com/2014/11/08/typhoon-haiyans-legacy-one-year-later/|title=Being There for the Victims of Typhoon Haiyan: One Year Later|last=Neidermeier|first=Ariel|date=2014-11-08|publisher=Asana News|accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref> For this program Project Leyte designed 40 two-story disaster resilient homes in order to focus on building upwards in a community where space for homes is limited. [[2014 Pacific typhoon season#Typhoon Hagupit|Typhoon Hagupit]] struck the area late in the year, delaying construction activities in Tacloban. The construction team helped both during the preparation and immediate response phases. Immediately following Typhoon Hagupit, the AHV Disaster Assessment Response Team (DART) spent six days on the island of [[Samar]], which bore the brunt of the typhoon assessing the island. All Hands found a village, [[Calampong]], where the organization began a traditional disaster cleanup, clearing fallen trees and debris, and deconstructing ruined homes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://airlinkflight.org/typhoon-hagupit-response/|title=Typhoon Hagupit Response|publisher=Airlink Flight|accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref>
===2013=== In 2013, the organization conducted the second phase of their response to Typhoon Sendong, building 88 new permanent homes for the victims of the storm.<ref name="gmanetwork1" /> In May, they set up a rapid response in the Rancho Brazos community in [[Granbury, Texas]], following a tornado in that area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blogsouthwest.com/all-hands-volunteers-and-southwest-help-rebuild-moore-ok/|title=All Hands Volunteers and Southwest Help Rebuild Moore, OK « Nuts About Southwest|last=Sawyer|first=Rachel|date=2013-06-05|publisher=Blogsouthwest.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> Immediately afterward, they moved to Oklahoma, to aid in restorations after [[Tornado outbreak of May 18–21, 2013|more tornadoes had hit]] in the areas of Moore and El Reno.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ertribune.com/?p=7892|title=Southwest employees lend a hand to those affected by tornado | El Reno Tribune|date=|publisher=Ertribune.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x10z6l9_all-hands-volunteers-and-southwest-airlines-employees-team-up-to-support-tornado-recovery-efforts-in_news?from_related=related.page.int.meta2-only.fd53d077b92d2678110e5942a5491167139230196|title=All Hands Volunteers and Southwest Airlines Employees Team up to Support Tornado Recovery Efforts in Oklahoma - Video Dailymotion|author=ON|date=2013-06-17|publisher=Dailymotion.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> In September 2013, the group set up an operation in Northeast Colorado following [[2013 Colorado floods|massive flooding]].<ref>[http://news.psu.edu/story/292965/2013/10/27/impact/abington-employees-provide-relief-colorado-flood-victims Abington employees provide relief to Colorado flood victims | Penn State University<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/colorado-floods-how-help-v20478394|title=Colorado floods: How to help|date=2013-09-16|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> They organized volunteer teams, helping residents and business owners clear debris and salvage belongings, as well as helping farmers clear debris from their fields.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reporterherald.com/news/colorado-flood/ci_25099887/volunteers-help-reflections-youth-restore-flood-damaged-building|title=Volunteers help Reflections for Youth restore flood-damaged building - Loveland Reporter-Herald|date=2013-09-12|publisher=Reporterherald.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wcfcourier.com/news/local/cedar-falls-residents-help-with-colorado-cleanup/article_3ba29f9a-575c-5c60-a74f-d6fa798aa00e.html|title=Cedar Falls residents help with Colorado cleanup|date=2013-10-03|publisher=Wcfcourier.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
In October, the group responded to [[2013 Bohol earthquake|a 7.2 earthquake in the island province of Bohol, Philippines]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://verafiles.org/new-american-envoy-captures-hearts-of-boholanos/|title=New American envoy captures hearts of Boholanos|date=2013-12-13|publisher=Vera Files|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> The group performed debris removal and salvage.<ref name="villagesoup1" /> While the project in Bohol continued, the group set up a second response site on the nearby Island of Leyte in response to [[Typhoon Yolanda]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2013/12/11/1261865/-All-Hands-Volunteers-Project-Bohol-at-work-in-earthquake-devastated-Antiquera-on-Bohol-Island|title=All Hands Volunteers Project Bohol at work in earthquake devastated Antiquera on Bohol Island|author=Lefty Coaster|date=2013-12-11|publisher=Daily Kos|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> Volunteers on Leyte worked to demolish damaged structures and deliver food to rural residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.somdnews.com/article/20140108/NEWS/140109421/1103/Huntingtown-native-volunteers-in-the-Philippines-after-devastating-typhoon&template=southernMaryland|title=Huntingtown native volunteers in the Philippines after devastating typhoon|date=|publisher=SoMdNews.com|accessdate=2014-02-13|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140314195640/http://www.somdnews.com/article/20140108/NEWS/140109421/1103/Huntingtown-native-volunteers-in-the-Philippines-after-devastating-typhoon&template=southernMaryland|archive-date=2014-03-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20131121/NEWS/131129937|title=Bermudian arrives in Philippines to help in aid effort | The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News|author=Jonathan Bell|date=|publisher=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> At the same time, the group set up a stateside response project in [[Washington, Illinois]] following a series of tornadoes in November 2013. FEMA had denied aid to the area, saying that infrastructure damage after the storms wasn't severe enough to warrant federal help.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pekintimes.com/article/20131227/NEWS/131229397|title=Tornado recovery volunteers hail from Alaska - News - Pekin Daily Times - Pekin, IL - Pekin, IL|date=2013-12-27|publisher=Pekintimes.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?id=9387794|title=FEMA denies Washington, Illinois tornado aid | abc7chicago.com|author=|date=2014-01-09|publisher=Abclocal.go.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
===2012=== Following the addition of teaching programs in Leogane, All Hands concluded their presence in Leogane.<ref name="ngoaidmap1">{{cite web|url=http://haiti.ngoaidmap.org/organizations/5|title=All Hands Volunteers - Haiti Aid Map|date=|publisher=Haiti.ngoaidmap.org|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gse.harvard.edu/news-impact/2012/11/disaster-relief-masters-candidate-alaina-bearden/|title=Disaster Relief: Master’s Candidate Alaina Bearden | Harvard Graduate School of Education|date=2012-11-16|publisher=Gse.harvard.edu|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> They established a presence in the Philippines with Project Cagayan de Oro, aiding in the cleanup and rebuilding efforts following [[Typhoon Sendong]] which hit on December 16, 2011, leaving at least 1,200 people dead, and destroying 50,000 houses.<ref name="gmanetwork1" /><ref>[http://www.whidbeynewstimes.com/news/232198731.html Coupeville man heading to Philippines as volunteer - Whidbey News-Times<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://r10.pia.gov.ph/index.php?article=1461341305860|title=PIA-R10 | 190 more houses to be constructed for Sendong survivors|date=2013-02-01|publisher=R10.pia.gov.ph|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/26749/hands-on-help-from-foreign-volunteers|title=Hands-on help from foreign volunteers | Inquirer Global Nation|date=2012-02-25|publisher=Globalnation.inquirer.net|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
In March 2012, they provided aid in coordinating volunteers for debris removal in [[Morgan County, KY]] after an EF-3 tornado caused a large amount of damage and killed six.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themoreheadnews.com/local/x1888228812/EF-3-tornado-brings-death-destruction-to-Morgan-County|title=EF-3 tornado brings death, destruction to Morgan County » Local News|last=Kappes|first=Keith|date=|publisher=The Morehead News|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citizencommandcenter.org/shelters/show/9106|title=Facility: VRC (Volunteer Reception Center), West Liberty, KY (Supported by: All Hands Volunteers) 3/12 Tornadoes (CitizenActionTeam.org Database)|date=|publisher=Citizencommandcenter.org|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> Following the June flooding of [[Duluth, MN]], the group aided in the restoration efforts, establishing a volunteer center where efforts could be coordinated, and flood victims could be matched with volunteers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.postbulletin.com/news/local/volunteers-help-flood-victims-rebuild-their-lives/article_e61c6ac5-8aab-507e-8dcb-cd0c35699ae6.html|title=Volunteers help flood victims rebuild their lives - PostBulletin.com: Local|date=2012-07-07|publisher=PostBulletin.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/event/article/id/235733/|title=Flood briefs: Hiking, biking trails remain closed | Duluth News Tribune | Duluth, Minnesota|date=2012-06-30|publisher=Duluth News Tribune|accessdate=2014-02-13}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Following [[Hurricane Isaac (2012)|Hurricane Isaac]], the group returned to the Mississippi Gulf Coast to provide hurricane recovery aid in the same region where HandsOnUSA had been formed to aid in the Katrina recovery efforts, providing cleanup and home repairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.fema.gov/blog/2012/09/17/volunteer-highlight-helping-rebuild-after-hurricane-isaac|title=Volunteer highlight: Helping to rebuild after Hurricane Isaac | Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA)|date=2012-09-17|publisher=M.fema.gov|accessdate=2014-02-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018041828/http://m.fema.gov/blog/2012/09/17/volunteer-highlight-helping-rebuild-after-hurricane-isaac|archive-date=2014-10-18|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://citizencommandcenter.org/shelters/show/9339|title=Facility: All Hands Volunteers (VOLUNTEER OPS) - 2012 HURRICANE ISAAC (CitizenActionTeam.org Database)|date=2012-09-17|publisher=Citizencommandcenter.org|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> The same season, they were situated on Staten Island and Long Island following [[Hurricane Sandy]], gutting houses and aiding in cleanup and restorative efforts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/04/29/hurricane-sandy-anniversary-a-reminder-of-the-power-of-volunteers.html|title=Hurricane Sandy Anniversary a Reminder of the Power of Volunteers|author=|date=|publisher=The Daily Beast|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fema.gov/disaster/4085/updates/hurricane-sandy-volunteer|title=Hurricane Sandy Volunteer|author=|date=2012-01-07|publisher=FEMA.gov|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> Volunteers in Long Beach, Long Island slept on the second floor of a church during the restorative efforts, staying there for eight months.<ref name="forbes1" />
===2011=== [[File:All Hands Volunteers at Project Tohoku.jpg|thumb|left|alt=|All Hands Volunteers clearing debris following the 2011 Japan earthquake.]]Relief efforts in Haiti continued in 2011, with the organization, now known as All Hands Volunteers (AHV), expanding to address the evolving needs of residents.<ref name="ngoaidmap1" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec2-204-236-230-77.compute-1.amazonaws.com/nonprofit/all-hands-volunteers/project-leogane-extends-2012|title=Volunteer Opportunity with All Hands Volunteers: Project Leogane Extends Into 2012 | Causecast for Nonprofits|date=|publisher=Ec2-204-236-230-77.compute-1.amazonaws.com|accessdate=2014-02-13|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140314195713/http://ec2-204-236-230-77.compute-1.amazonaws.com/nonprofit/all-hands-volunteers/project-leogane-extends-2012|archive-date=2014-03-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> One aspect of this involved the creation of a Biosand Filter Program to distribute water filters that kill pathogens and prevent the spread of waterborne diseases to Leogane and surrounding rural communities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://66.147.244.207/~csfukorg/our-projects/water-filtration-and-sanitation/|title=Water Filtration and Sanitation | Child Survival Fund|date=2010-01-12|publisher=66.147.244.207|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> Another was the creation of a Livelihoods program, which educated residents in business skills in order to increase their standard of living.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vimeo.com/31811462|title=What Is The Livelihoods Program? on Vimeo|author=All Hands Volunteers|date=2011-11-08|publisher=Vimeo.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> They also collaborated with other relief agencies on the Vini Jwe project, which constructed a soccer field for the community Leogane, commemorating its completion with a tournament involving international aid organizations, Haitian league teams and members of the local community.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tim-jahnigen/lending-all-hands-to-hait_b_847303.html|title=Tim Jahnigen: Lending All Hands to Haiti|date=2011-04-11|accessdate=2014-02-13|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com}}</ref>
On March 11th, 2011 a magnitude 9.1 earthquake struck off of the coast of Tohoku, Japan, triggering a devastating tsunami which struck the region. In response, The organization launched Project Tohoku, setting up operations in [[Rikuzentakata, Iwate|Rikuzentakata]] city and [[Ofunato]] city, [[Iwate Prefecture]], where approximately 7,200 homes were badly damaged by [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|the earthquake and tsunami]].<ref name="world1" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emrojapan.com/emnews/content/420.html|title=ALL HANDS Volunteer Group - Project Tohoku|date=2011-07-22|publisher=Emrojapan.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> There, they worked with hundreds of volunteers to clear debris from homes, canals, and public areas and repaired houses.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/07/06/destin-nation-japan-volun_n_928576.html#s331506title=Iwate_Prefecture|title=Destin-Nation Japan: Voluntourism After The Disaster (PHOTOS)|date=2011-07-06|accessdate=2014-02-13|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com}}</ref>
All Hands also established relief efforts in the U.S., following tornadoes that struck in Alabama, Massachusetts and Missouri.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewsdispatch.com/articles/2011/09/02/news/local/doc4e5ad8ff47434973425696.txt|title=> Archives > News > Local > City native completes Americorps program|date=2011-09-02|publisher=The News Dispatch|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/18/post_677_n_850795.html|title=Tornadoes 2011: Strangers Across 6 States Help Victims Cope|date=2011-04-18|accessdate=2014-02-13|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com}}</ref> A "Good Friday" EF-4 tornado struck [[St. Louis]] on Friday, April 22. AHV's debris clearance team spent four weeks, beginning in May, clearing trees from buildings. A longer-term effort began in May to help relocate families and to de-construct houses that had to be gutted prior to being rebuilt.<ref name="urlSt. Louis Tornado">{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/st-louis-tornado-response/|title=St. Louis Tornado Response|date=|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-11-06}}</ref> Dozens of tornados struck Alabama on [[2011 Super Outbreak#April 27|April 27]] in a super outbreak which killed over 200 people. AHV responded to requests by the State and the Alabama branch of VOAD to provide inter-agency coordination services in support of the ongoing recovery efforts. Coordination of needs was enhanced by a strong [[2-1-1]] system. Direct volunteer efforts included tree removal, debris removal, and de-construction. AHV efforts concluded in mid-July.<ref name="urlAL Tornado">{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/alabama-tornado-response/|title=Alabama Tornado Response|date=|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-11-06}}</ref> While the Alabama recovery was underway, [[Western Massachusetts]] was hit by multiple tornados on June 1. The Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency (MEMA) asked AHV to provide coordination services for volunteer agencies in the state. At the same time AHV partnered with United Way and using the 2-1-1 system provided field operations support throughout much of Western Massachusetts to match unaffiliated volunteers with agencies to assist in debris clean-up and roof and home repair.<ref name="urlSpringfieldMA Tornado">{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/springfield-tornado-response/|title=Springfield Tornado Response|date=|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-11-06}}</ref>
AHV provided flood relief in [[Minot, ND]], where [[2011 Souris River flood|the June flooding of the Souris River]] forced 10,000 residents to flee and damaged more than 4,100 properties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.minotdailynews.com/page/content.detail/id/557913/All-hands-on-deck--Volunteers-come-from-all-over-to-help-Minot.html?nav=5010|title=All hands on deck: Volunteers come from all over to help Minot - MinotDailyNews.com | News, sports, business, jobs|date=2011-08-24|publisher=Minot Daily News|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alfredstate.edu/news/2011-08-25/staff-to-embark-on-relief-trip-to-minot-nd|title=Staff to Embark On Relief Trip to Minot, ND | Alfred State|date=2011-08-25|publisher=Alfredstate.edu|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
They were also in the [[Catskills]] following [[Hurricane Irene]], cleaning up damaged buildings and clearing debris.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://untappedcities.com/2011/09/22/catskills-still-reeling-from-irene-but-not-forgotten/|title=Catskills Still Reeling from Irene, But Not Forgotten|date=|publisher=Untapped Cities|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
===2010=== On January 12, 2010, [[2010 Haiti earthquake|an earthquake that registered 7.0 on the Richter Scale struck Haiti]], with a death toll that some estimates quoted as high as 300,000, with another 300,000 wounded and more than one million people left homeless.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1953347,00.html|title=Haiti Earthquake: Could It Have Been Predicted? - TIME|last=Kluger|first=Jeffrey|date=2010-01-13|accessdate=2014-02-12|publisher=Content.time.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/centralamericaandthecaribbean/haiti/7621756/Haitis-earthquake-death-toll-revised-to-at-least-250000.html|title=Haiti's earthquake death toll revised to at least 250,000|author=|date=2010-04-22|accessdate=2014-02-12|publisher=Telegraph|location=London}}</ref> The first volunteer staff from HODR arrived on January 21 where, after networking with contacts from their previous efforts in Gonaives, they launched Project Leogane on February 3, 2010 with an emphasis on deconstruction and salvage, as well as in the building of transitional schools. In what would become the organization's longest running project, HODR would remain until 2012 (by which time they would be known as All Hands Volunteers).<ref name="bsces1" />
HODR also returned to the [[Cedar Rapids, Iowa]] area in April 2010, to aid in continued rebuilding following the 2008 flood, with the help of a $15,000 donation from the Greater Cedar Rapids Home Builders Association to pay for tools and supplies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thegazette.com/2010/04/09/hands-on-disaster-response-returns-to-help-with-rebuilding/#ixzz2t7uASb25|title=Hands On Disaster Response returns to help with rebuilding|date=|publisher=TheGazette|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
The group aided with flood recovery coordination for three U.S. incidents, establishing operations in Rhode Island, Tennessee and Iowa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uml.edu/News/stories/2010-11/haiti_relief_speaker.aspx|title=Saving the World, One Volunteer at a Time|date=2004-12-26|publisher=Uml.edu|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> Rhode Island received up to {{convert|15|in|abbr=on}} of rain in late March and subsequently suffered severe flooding. HODR responded to a request by the state branch of [[VOAD]] and the state's emergency management agency to establish and staff an inter-agency recovery coordination center (RCC). The center continued providing coordination until early May.<ref name="urlRI RCC">{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/rhode-island-flood-coordination/|title=Rhode Island Flood Coordination|date=|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> As the Rhode Island project concluded, both [[Middle Tennessee|Middle]] and [[West Tennessee]] experienced record rainfall and [[2010 Tennessee floods|suffered exceptional flooding]]. Similar to the Rhode Island project, HODR helped optimize an RCC in [[Antioch, Tennessee]] that subsequently handled over a thousand inter-agency requests for assistance.<ref name="urlTN RCC">{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/tennessee-flood-coordination/|title=Tennessee Flood Coordination|date=|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> In August, the [[Skunk River]] flooded parts of southern Iowa. Especially devastated was the city of [[Colfax, Iowa|Colfax]] in [[Jasper County, Iowa|Jasper County]]. HODR teams helped with clean-up and recovery activities plus assisting in inter-agency coordination for Colfax and Jasper County.<ref name="urlJasper CountyIA RCC">{{cite web|url=http://hands.org/projects/jasper-county-flood-coordination/|title=Jasper County Flood Coordination|date=|publisher=All Hands Volunteers|accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref>
===2009=== In April 2009, HODR set up operations in [[Mena, Arkansas]] to remove debris and downed trees after an EF3 [[April 2009 tornado outbreak#Mena tornado|tornado hit the town]], damaging more than 600 homes and affecting thousands of people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guidestar.org/PartnerReport.aspx?ein=20-2142644&Partner=Amex|title=Amex-Organization Report|date=|publisher=GuideStar|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
A coordination team was deployed to [[Gowanda, NY]], following the August 9–10, 2009 flash flooding in [[Cattaraugus County, New York|Cattaraugus County]], where they set up a recovery center at the Gowanda Fire Department to connect agencies with volunteers seeking to help in flood recovery in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cattco.org/content/august-2009-flood-information|title=August 2009 Flood Information | Cattaraugus County|date=|publisher=Cattco.org|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmcnet.com/usubmit/2009/08/22/4335371.htm|title=Hospital's future still under review [The Buffalo News, N.Y.]|date=|publisher=Tmcnet.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
In October, the group opened Project Sungai Geringging after [[2009 Sumatra earthquakes|Western Sumatra was hit by a 7.9 magnitude earthquake]] on September 30.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicforrelief.org/profiles/blogs/update-hands-on-disaster|title=Update: Hands On Disaster Response In Indonesia - Project Sungai Geringging|date=2010-03-24|publisher=Music For Relief|accessdate=2014-02-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130724220525/http://www.musicforrelief.org/profiles/blogs/update-hands-on-disaster|archive-date=2013-07-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The project operated until April 2010, demolishing damaged structures and salvaging reusable materials to aid in rebuilding.<ref name="bsces1" />
===2008=== In February, the organization established a three-week operation in [[Gassville, Arkansas]], to aid in the cleanup after a category [[Enhanced Fujita scale|EF2 tornado]], one of the [[2008 Super Tuesday tornado outbreak|Super Tuesday tornados]], struck the town destroying 79 homes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baxtercountysheriff.com/e_newsletter_view.php?id=7|title=TORNADO DEVASTATES LARGE SECTIONS OF GASSVILLE: - Baxter County Sheriff's Office|date=|publisher=Baxtercountysheriff.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cornwall-on-hudson.com/event.cfm?page=1963|title=Latest News in Cornwall-On-Hudson, NY : : Local resident gives disaster relief|date=|publisher=Cornwall On Hudson|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> They then moved to [[Newton County, Missouri]], to aid with the recovery after the [[Mid-May 2008 tornado outbreak sequence#Picher/Neosho tornado|Picher/Neosho tornado]] on May 10 hit the county, destroying almost 200 houses and killing 18.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bonaresponds.blogspot.com/2008/05/neosho-missouri-weather-and-forecast.html|title=BonaResponds Blog: Neosho, Missouri Weather and forecast|author=FinanceProfessor|date=2008-05-20|publisher=Bonaresponds.blogspot.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
In June 2008, [[Iowa flood of 2008|eastern Iowa was hit with massive flooding]], forcing the evacuation of several cities, including [[Palo, Iowa|Palo]] and [[Cedar Rapids, Iowa|Cedar Rapids]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kcrg.com/floodwatch/video/linn|title=KCRG-TV9 | Cedar Rapids, Iowa News, Sports, and Weather | Linn County|date=|publisher=Kcrg.com|accessdate=2014-02-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090610083340/http://www.kcrg.com/floodwatch/video/linn|archive-date=2009-06-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> HODR established Project Cedar Rapids, bringing over 2,000 volunteers to the area during its four-month deployment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.bcccc.net/2009/05/corporate-disaster-relief-best-practices-and-lessons-learned/|title=Corporate disaster relief: Best practices and lessons learned « Blog Archive « Boston College Center for Corporate Citizenship Blog|date=2009-05-15|publisher=Blogs.bcccc.net|accessdate=2014-02-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140205115328/http://blogs.bcccc.net/2009/05/corporate-disaster-relief-best-practices-and-lessons-learned/|archive-date=2014-02-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Volunteers traveled door to door, assisting residents with clean up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kcrg.com/news/local/20817894.html|title=Preserving Palo... Flood Victims Rebuild | KCRG-TV9 | Cedar Rapids, Iowa News, Sports, and Weather | Local News|last=Ogann|first=Becky|date=2008-06-24|publisher=Kcrg.com|accessdate=2014-02-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018045940/http://www.kcrg.com/news/local/20817894.html|archive-date=2014-10-18|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
HODR's final project in 2008 took place in [[Gonaives, Haiti]], after [[2008 Atlantic hurricane season|a series of hurricanes]] hit the area, where the group aided in mud removal and the rebuilding of the city's infrastructure, including the cleaning and painting of the school and medical clinic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bc.edu/publications/chronicle/TopstoriesNewFeatures/features/haiti022909.html|title=The Boston College Chronicle - Boston College|date=2008-06-24|publisher=Bc.edu|accessdate=2014-02-13|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140314195610/http://www.bc.edu/publications/chronicle/TopstoriesNewFeatures/features/haiti022909.html|archive-date=2014-03-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===2007=== The organization's next project took place in [[Pisco, Peru]], providing aid following the [[2007 Peru earthquake]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maplegreen.com/peru/peru02.asp|title=Hands On in Peru, Oct./Nov. 2007|date=|publisher=Maplegreen.com|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=123744232|title=How Can Outsiders Help Communities In Crisis?|author=Talk of the Nation|date=2010-02-15|publisher=NPR|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> The group's final project in 2007 was in Rayenda, Bangladesh, following [[Cyclone Sidr]], where they aided in restoration with a group of 50 volunteers from 10 different countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/portfolios/samples_files/4881_ZkgunKJ1fR4nb7v_ru9gufLsD.pdf|title=After The Storm|author=Libby Ellis|date=February 2009|publisher=PM Network|accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
=== 2006 === On May 27, 2006, an [[2006 Yogyakarta earthquake|earthquake measuring 6.3]] on the Richter scale struck the [[Yogyakarta]] region in [[Java, Indonesia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/templates/tc/tce/pdf/Indonesia_Farming_Strategy_Jan07.pdf |title=FARMING-RELATED LIVELIHOODS REHABILITATION STRATEGY FOR THE DISASTER-AFFECTED AREAS OF YOGYAKARTA AND CENTRAL JAVA PROVINCES |publisher=Government of the Republic of Indonesia |date=January 2007 |accessdate=2014-10-10}}</ref> HODR established a base in the village of Sawit, where volunteers participated in demolition and debris removal.<ref>{{cite web|author = |url=https://givingcommon.guidestar.org/ViewEdoc.aspx?eDocId=2728526&approved=True |title=2013 Annual Report |publisher=All Hands Volunteers |date=2013 |accessdate=2014-10-10}}</ref>
In November 2006, [[Typhoon Durian|Typhoon Durian (Reming)]] struck the Philippines, resulting in extensive damage and loss of life.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brown |first=Sophie |url=http://world.time.com/2013/11/11/the-philippines-is-the-most-storm-exposed-country-on-earth/ |title=The Philippines: Typhoon Facts | TIME.com |publisher=World.time.com |date=2013-11-11 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> HODR established a base in the township of [[Santo Domingo, Albay]] in January 2007, assisting with rebuilding and cleanup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maplegreen.com/durian/ |title=Hands On in the Philippines, Jan/Feb 2007 |publisher=Maplegreen.com |date=2006-11-30 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://u000030206.photoshelter.com/image/I0000J1gp.jWJqA4 |title=Hands On Disaster Response (Usa) Conducts Typhoon Relief In The Philippines | Ninfa Bito |publisher=U000030206.photoshelter.com |date=2007-02-13 |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref>
==Leadership==
*[[David N. Campbell|David Campbell]], Chair and Co-founder - Formerly the CEO of Computer Task Group (CTG) and Xpedior, and President of BBN Technologies, Campbell came up with the idea of the business model surrounding All Hands while volunteering in Thailand in the aftermath of the 2004 Sumatran tsunami, using it to first launch Hands On Thailand and making it the structure for the evolution of the organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.innovationadvisors.com/Campbell.html|title=David Campbell|publisher=Innovation Advisors}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author =Kerry Hannon |url=http://money.usnews.com/money/personal-finance/articles/2009/10/07/second-act-careers-from-head-honcho-to-humanitarian |title=Second-Act Careers: From Head Honcho to Humanitarian - US News |publisher=Money.usnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> Campbell served as the organization's executive director until 2013, when Erik Dyson was named as the new director.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://www.pbn.com/Five-Questions-With-Erik-Dyson,90208?print=1 |title=Five Questions With: Erik Dyson - Providence Business News |publisher=Pbn.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> *[[Petra Němcová]], Vice Chair - A Czech [[Fashion model|model]], television host and philanthropist who founded the Happy Hearts Fund in 2005 following her personal experiences during the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|2004 Boxing Day Tsunami.]] In addition to her successful career, Němcová remains heavily involved in promoting global awareness of disaster response, being recognised for her work with the Happy hearts Fund as well as being appointed by the [[United Nations International Strategy for Disaster Reduction|UNISDR]] as a Disaster Risk Reduction Champion and Tsunami Awareness Advocate in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unisdr.org/archive/55748|title=Tsunami Advocate Focuses On Safe Schools - UNISDR|website=www.unisdr.org|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> *Erik Dyson, Executive Director - Previously the senior vice president of Latin America for GTECH Corp., Dyson has also worked in commercial real estate in the Boston area, and served for three years in El Salvador and Costa Rica with Habitat for Humanity International. He holds an MBA in Business Administration from the Harvard Business School.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
==Awards and honours== *In 2005, Darius Monsef was given the [[key to the city]] of Biloxi, Mississippi by A.J. Holloway for his organization's work in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.<ref name=portlandtribune1 /> *In 2006, David Campbell was named a Purpose Prize Fellow 2006 by [[Encore.org]].<ref name="David Campbell"/> *In 2011, All Hands received an Innovator Award for the Best CRM Visionary/Use of Common Ground at the Convio Innovator Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.convio.com/signup/innovatorawards/2011/best-crm-visionary.html |title=Innovator Awards 2011: Best CRM Visionary / Use of Common Groundâ"¢ |publisher=Convio |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13}}</ref> *In 2013, David Campbell was awarded with the [[Richard Cornuelle]] Award for Social Entrepreneurship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manhattan-institute.org/html/se_winners.htm |title=Social Entrepreneurship Award Winners |publisher=Manhattan Institute |date= |accessdate=2014-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140329065639/http://www.manhattan-institute.org/html/se_winners.htm |archivedate=March 29, 2014 }}</ref> *In 2014, All Hands received the National Voluntary Organizations Active in Disaster (NVOAD) Member of the Year Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.borgenmagazine.com/all-hands-volunteers-disaster-relief-worldwide/|title=All Hands Volunteers: Disaster Relief Worldwide|work=Borgen Magazine |accessdate=2014-10-09}}</ref> *In 2014, Founder and Chairman- David Campbell was announced as Encore.org Purpose Prize Award winner *In 2015, All Hands Volunteers wins Make a Difference A Day Award *In 2015 All Hands Volunteers rank one of the top ten NGO's for Data Quality Award *In 2015, [[David N. Campbell|David Campbell]] won the [[Points of Light]] Award *In 2017, Petra was appointed by the [[United Nations International Strategy for Disaster Reduction|UNISDR]] as a Disaster Risk Reduction Champion and Tsunami Awareness Advocate<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unisdr.org/archive/55742|title=UN Appoints Tsunami Survivor as Global Advocate - UNISDR|website=www.unisdr.org|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref> *In 2018, All Hands And Hearts were ranked #1 on the Classy 100, topping a list of fastest growing NGO's for 2017. *In 2018, All Hands And Hearts were ranked as 4 stars by Charity Navigator, indicating exceptional financial and operational efficiency.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=13109|title=Charity Navigator - Rating for All Hands and Hearts Smart Response|website=Charity Navigator|language=en|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Commons category|All Hands Volunteers}} {{Official website|https://www.allhandsandhearts.org}} * http://encore.org/purpose-prize/david-campbell/ *Annual financial reports: https://www.allhandsandhearts.org/about-us/our-financials/

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Bad Company | image = Mauvaises Fréquentations DVD cover.jpg | image size = | caption = DVD cover | director = [[Jean-Pierre Améris]] | producer = [[Philippe Godeau]]
[[Alain Sarde]] | writer = [[Alain Layrac]] | narrator = | starring = [[Maud Forget]]
[[Lou Doillon]] | music = | cinematography = Yves Vandermeeren | editing = Martine Giordano | distributor = Universal Pictures France | released = {{start date|df=yes|1999|10|20}} | runtime = 98 minutes | country = France | language = French | budget = $3.8 million | gross = $3.5 millionhttp://www.jpbox-office.com/fichfilm.php?id=2781 }} '''''Bad Company''''' (original title: '''''Mauvaises Fréquentations''''') is a 1999 French film starring [[Maud Forget]] and [[Lou Doillon]]. It is a romantic drama about two young students falling in love. The movie is written by [[Alain Layrac]], and directed by [[Jean-Pierre Améris]]. A few scenes from this movie are featured in a music video by [[Lene Marlin]] for her song, ''Where I'm Headed''. == Cast == * [[Maud Forget]] : Delphine * [[Lou Doillon]] : Olivia * [[Robinson Stévenin]] : Laurent * [[François Berleand]] : René * [[Ariane Ascaride]] : Olivia's Mother * [[Maxime Mansion]] : Alain * [[Cyril Cagnat]] : Justin * [[Delphine Rich]] : Claire ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0211504|title=Bad Company}} {{Jean-Pierre Améris}} {{Philippe Godeau}} [[Category:1999 films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Jean-Pierre Améris]] [[Category:Pan-Européenne films]] [[Category:1990s romantic drama films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Films about prostitution]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] {{1990s-romantic-drama-film-stub}} {{1990s-France-film-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox military conflict| conflict=Incident of Pacocha |colour_scheme=background:#ffccaa;color:#2222cc | image= Combate de Pacocha.jpg | image_size= 300px | caption= Battle of Pacocha | date=29 May 1877 | place=SE Pacific Ocean |result= Indecisive | combatant1={{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[United Kingdom]] | combatant2=[[Peru]]vian rebels | commander1=[[Algernon Frederick Rous de Horsey|de Horsey]] | commander2= Luis Germán [[Astete (surname)|Astete]] | strength1=1 unarmoured ship: {{HMS|Shah|1873|6}}
1 wooden ship: {{HMS|Amethyst|1873|6}} | strength2=1 ironclad ship: [[Huáscar (ship)|''Huáscar'']] | casualties1= | casualties2= |}} The naval '''Incident of Pacocha''' took place on 29 May 1877 when [[Nicolás de Piérola]] was leading a revolution to overthrow then [[Peru]]vian President [[Mariano Ignacio Prado]]. Piérola's supporters used the Peruvian monitor [[Huáscar (ship)|''Huáscar'']] as a raiding ship. She harassed the shipping especially off [[El Callao]], the main commercial port of Peru. However, after she boarded some British merchant ships, British authorities sent Rear Admiral [[Algernon Frederick Rous de Horsey|de Horsey]] to capture the vessel. The Peruvian warship managed to outrun the British squadron after a fierce exchange of fire. ''Huáscar''{{'}}s guns were undermanned, and she fired just 40 rounds. ''Shah''{{'}}s mast was damaged by splinters. On the British side, ''Shah'' fired 237 shots and ''Amethyst'' 190, but none of them carried armour-piercing ammunition. ''Huáscar'' was hit 60 times, but her armour shield defeated all the rounds. There was a last-ditch effort to stop or sink the rebels when two small [[torpedo ram]]s from ''Shah'' attempted to find the ''Huáscar'', but the Peruvian ship managed to escape under the cover of darkness. The rebel crew was forced to surrender their ship to the Peruvian government just two days later. This battle saw the first use of the newly invented self-propelled [[torpedo]] which, at the time, had just entered limited service with the [[Royal Navy]]. The torpedo was dodged by the rebel monitor. == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040803142718/http://members.lycos.co.uk/Juan39/BATTLE_OF_PACOCHA.html Specifics of the Incident] {{coord missing|Pacific Ocean}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pacocha}} [[Category:Naval battles involving the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Naval battles involving Peru]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1877]] [[Category:International maritime incidents]] [[Category:Peru–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 1877]] [[Category:May 1877 events]] {{UK-battle-stub}}
